metadata.case_name: Seth Gambir Mal Pandiya v. J. K. Jute Mills Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Messrs. J. K. Jute Mills Co. Ltd. entered into a contract with the firm Messrs. Birdhi Chand Sumer Mal for the supply of certain articles.
The contract was entered into by Seth Tikam Chand, a partner in the firm.
One of the terms of the contract was that in case of a dispute between the parties, it would be referred to the Merchants Chamber of Commerce, Kanpur, for arbitration.
A dispute arose, which was referred to the Chamber of Commerce, and an award in favour of the Mills was given on January 8, 1947.
Two years later, the award was made into a rule of the Court, and a decree followed in favour of the Mills.
The firm of Birdhi Chand Sumer Mal consisted of two partners: Seth Tikam Chand and Mr. Pandiya, the predecessor-in-interest of Seth Gambir Mal Pandiya, the appellant.
In execution of the decree passed against the firm, the Mills wished to proceed against the personal property of Mr. Pandiya and filed an application for leave of the Court under O.21, r.50(2), CPC.

Seth Gambir Mal Pandiya appeared and raised objections: he had not been served in the proceedings relating to the arbitration, making and filing of the award in Court; Seth Tikam Chand had no authority to enter into an agreement containing such a clause or to refer the dispute to arbitration on behalf of the other partners; the award was not binding on him.
The First Civil Judge, Kanpur, allowed the application of the Mills and granted them leave under the rule.
The appellant filed a revision petition in the Allahabad High Court (Civil Revision No. 815 of 1955).

Agarwala, J. held that the decree was binding only against partnership property and personally against persons in cls. (b) and (e) of r.50(1), O.21; not binding against appellant who had not been served unless summons served under sub-r.(2) and liability determined; appellant could question personal liability on ground that decree resulted from award based on arbitration agreement to which he was not a party.
Beg, J. held that since appellant admitted he was a partner, he was not entitled to raise objection to the contract, reference to arbitration or award.
Mukherji, J. agreed with Beg, J.; revision dismissed by order dated September 25, 1957.
High Court certified case fit for appeal to Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: What kind of defences are open to a person summoned under O.21 r.50(2) CPC against whom execution is sought as a partner in a firm, particularly whether they can challenge the validity of the arbitration agreement or reference if they admit being a partner.

petitioner_arguments.text: Appellant had not been served in the proceedings relating to arbitration, making and filing of award; Seth Tikam Chand had no authority to enter arbitration clause or refer dispute; award not binding personally.
Narrow construction: only whether partner; wide: all defences open to partnership not raised in suit plus personal defences; middle: personal liability.

respondent_arguments.text: If person summoned admits he is a partner, nothing further to try; execution can issue individually without trying other issues.

court_reasoning.text: O.21 r.50 deals with execution against firms; enables execution against partnership property, persons who appeared/admitted/adjudged partners, served but failed to appear; for others, leave after trying liability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Difficulty in meaning of 'the liability of such person'; defences open are limited.

court_reasoning.text: Provisions of O.30 CPC (suits against firms) and O.21 r.50 must be read together; derived from English RSC O.XLVIII r.a.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Suit proceeds against firm; partners served appear individually but defend firm.

court_reasoning.text: Person denying partnership cannot defend firm; admitting partners defend firm only, not inter se or personal defences beyond partnership.
court_reasoning.key_observation: English cases (Weir v. McVicar, Ellis v. Wadeson) establish defences: (1) not partner at material time; (2) collusion/fraud, but not reopen suit or personal against partners.

court_reasoning.text: Indian cases mostly align: only partnership at material time or collusion/fraud; later Bombay/Madras/Calcutta cases prefer narrow view over earlier broader ones like Bhagwan v. Hiraji.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Correct view: primarily whether partner when cause arose; may question on collusion/fraud but not retry suit or inter se issues.

court_reasoning.text: Appellant admits partnership, no collusion/fraud alleged; leave must be granted.

holdings.text: Under O.21 r.50(2) CPC, in inquiry for leave to execute decree against partner not served in suit, primary issue is whether person was partner when cause of action accrued; may also question decree on collusion/fraud etc., but cannot reopen merits of suit or raise inter se partner issues.

precedents_cited.case_name: Weir Co. v. Mc Vicar Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Person denying partnership cannot defend firm; issue under execution rule only whether partner at material time.
Partners admitting position defend firm only; personal defences not allowed.
Judgment against firm if action against firm.
Execution against unserved partner: opportunity to raise defences as if served in suit.
Issue: whether partner at material time or held out as such.
Only question: whether partner at material time.
Earlier view allowing challenge to arbitration authority rejected.

precedents_cited.case_name: C. M. Shahani v. Havero Trading Co.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs execution of decrees against firms and suits in firm name; interpreted to limit defences in execution inquiry.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Proviso in O.21 r.50(1) not limiting effects.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's dismissal of the revision petition, confirming leave granted to execute the decree against the appellant's personal property as he admitted being a partner and raised no plea of collusion or fraud.

key_quotes.text: "Once he admits that he is a partner and has no special defence of collusion, fraud, etc. the Court must give leave forthwith."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of inquiry under O.21 r.50(2).

key_quotes.text: "The proper meaning thus is that primarily the question to try would be whether the person against whom the decree is sought to be executed was a partner of the firm, when the cause of action accrued, but he may question the decree on the ground of collusion, fraud or the like."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines permissible defences in execution proceedings.
